body.p:
Yours 20th ? came to hand a
couple of days ago and I proceed to answer
its most important portion viz. I spoke
for a considerable length of time to Mr. Touro in your behalf stating what I
think he ought to do for you and other
as is my practice with him, left him
to ponder the matter. Meeting
with him again next day I asked
him if he had come to any conclu
sion in the premises upon which
he replied that (as I happen to know
to be the case just now) he had not
enough money on hand to pay pressing
demands, but he added that he had
a balance of $300 in the hands of David
Hart Esq New York which he would order him
to remit to you. Now whether he intends
to send you $700 from here or not I can
not say. I did not like to press him
on this point because you know
he is a strange man, and intending to
serve you, I might have injured your
claims. I choose to infer that he
will send you the 700 and after some

little time elapses I shall inquire
of him if he has written to Mr
Hart & if he has sent you the 700.
I think he will do it sooner or
later.

I thank you for the information
given in your letter. Your note to
Mr Isaac Hart I duly delivered.
With regard to publishing Dias's letter
you will meet with poor support
here. I suppose 20 or 30 copies could
be disposed of here in both congregations
provided the price does not exceed
50 to 75 cents.

Mr de Sola of Canada sent some
40 copies of English's work ? and
a number of pamphlets on the Sermon
on the Mount. I believe about 10
of the former only have been sold altho'
Gutheim & myself have tried to keep the sale.

Your Book, Bibleleft with me by Mr
Nathan I will bear in mind
altho' I fear it will be a long time
before I can sell them.

When your new Bible comes out
have the copy which I ordered for
myself strongly and handsomely bound
and my name printed on the cover

a few dollars more or less you need
not consider in my case.

I am still in correspondence with
Mr Eckman about China. His
advices from Dr. Adler are unsatisfactory
and yet I think I know the Jews
in this country too well, to believe
that anything will be done on this
side of the Atlantic. There are some
disturbances in China & throughout
the East & I pray the finger of Providence
may yet point out a release for the
unfortunate of our faith in the
Chinese Empire. Oh Leeser if I had
the wealth of some of my intimate
friends. What can I do? I assure
you no one knows how much I
have to do here in every way, in
everything connected with Judaism
many are the hours that I feel
so sick at heart that if I could
I would go and live beyond the reach
of man or at least of my own people.
I am poor and as yet have not
been able to pay off debts honorably
incurred in my previous unfortunate
business. It is a great question in my
mind if I have the right to do the
little charity which I do whilst I

am in debt; and then my very
manner of living, which is some-
what expensive and which nevertheless
I ought to continue for very many
good reasons, compels me to curtail
at times the amounts which I would
otherwise give away. But I hope
to continue to prosper in the world
in order to extend the benefits which
I ought bestow on others.

If I do not hear before long of a
proper person to fill the office of
Minister to our congregation, I think
I shall propose to the men here to alter
our advertisement simply to call
for a first rate Portuguese Hazan and
this I will do because I see now
that the majority care more for the
singing than for the preaching—
I have found it imperative upon me
even at this late day to pursue the course
recommended by Mr Calhoun ? “Masterly inac
tivity.” I have too much dead weight to
contend against & after struggling for
an end for nearly a score of years I have
now to yield, till a new generation arises
which so far as I can I am impregnating with the broad views & philanthropy of the
Mosaic teachings. My sister, Brother & theirs send you fond greetings. I am yours as ever faithfully,
